articles.headline: Wall St. Programmer Guilty of Code Theft
articles.snippet: The case against Sergey Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, brought attention to high-frequency trading by Wall Street firms.
articles.abstract: The case against Sergey Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, brought attention to high-frequency trading by Wall Street firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The case that put a spotlight on the world of ultra-fast, computer-driven trading of stocks has ended in a conviction.

articles.headline: Ireland Strives to Rebuild Trust in Its Banks
articles.snippet: The head of Ireland’s central bank says regulators must be more convincing that the worst will soon be over.
articles.abstract: The head of Ireland’s central bank says regulators must be more convincing that the worst will soon be over.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN  As the Irish government introduced the toughest budget in the nation’s history this week, Stephen Henry, a worker at a credit scoring service, paused to glower at the Anglo Irish Bank building facing St. Stephen’s Green in the heart of Dublin.

articles.headline: Choosing Recipients of Charity
articles.snippet: Start by setting a budget for giving, and then divide that pie according to the causes that are important to you.
articles.abstract: Start by setting a budget for giving, and then divide that pie according to the causes that are important to you.
articles.lead_paragraph: December is the season of solicitations, and besides the catalogs peddling obscure gadgets and enormous hunks of meat from the Great Plains, you’ve also probably received an impressive pile of pleas from various nonprofit institutions.

articles.headline: Why C.E.O.’s Should Stop at City Hall
articles.snippet: Wealthy executives can make for strong mayors, but their political ambitions should end there.
articles.abstract: Wealthy executives can make for strong mayors, but their political ambitions should end there.
articles.lead_paragraph: This past Wednesday, Jim Gray, a wealthy construction executive from Lexington, Ky., flew to New York City for a whirlwind round of meetings. Mr. Gray, 57, is the chief executive of Gray Construction, a family-owned business that builds large industrial facilities for the likes of Toyota, Siemens, Caterpillar and other giant manufacturers. It has around $500 million in annual revenue.

articles.headline: When Wrinkle-Free Clothing Also Means Formaldehyde Fumes
articles.snippet: Critics say more studies are needed on the effects of formaldehyde in textiles, including a closer look at the effects of cumulative exposure.
articles.abstract: Critics say more studies are needed on the effects of formaldehyde in textiles, including a closer look at the effects of cumulative exposure.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iron, that relic of households past, is no longer required to look neat and freshly pressed. Why bother when retailers like Nordstrom offer crisp “wrinkle-free finish” dress shirts and L. L. Bean sells chinos that are “great right out of the dryer.”

articles.headline: Gift Cards With Bells and Whistles
articles.snippet: Retailers are adding features like aromas, photos and recorded messages to make gift cards more attractive.
articles.abstract: Retailers are adding features like aromas, photos and recorded messages to make gift cards more attractive.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year, retailers’ gift cards record messages, light up or smell like gingerbread. Some feature the work of noted photographers, others incorporate personal photos. Some can be sent via text message or Facebook posts, and others are tactile (like the one with little holes for a finger puppet).

articles.headline: In Siberia Race, Ruling Party Uses Clenched Fist
articles.snippet: Efforts to suppress an opposition party in Siberia seem to underscore how laws intended to guarantee free and fair elections carry little weight in Russia.
articles.abstract: Efforts to suppress an opposition party in Siberia seem to underscore how laws intended to guarantee free and fair elections carry little weight in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia — On the eve of regional elections, an opposition candidate named Olga V. Safronova arrived at a school for a campaign finale. She planned a rousing speech with a refrain that Russia had been seized by a dictatorial ruling party.

articles.headline: A Madoff Son Hangs Himself on Father’s Arrest Anniversary
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff’s son Mark was found dead in his Manhattan apartment on the second anniversary of his father’s arrest.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff’s son Mark was found dead in his Manhattan apartment on the second anniversary of his father’s arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Madoff, the older of Bernard L. Madoff’s two sons, hanged himself in his Manhattan apartment on Saturday, the second anniversary of his father’s arrest for running a gigantic Ponzi scheme that shattered thousands of lives around the world.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Al Baker

articles.headline: The Nerve to Say No
articles.snippet: Joseph A. Smith Jr., the nominee to lead the Federal Housing Finance Agency, faces the huge job of figuring how to protect Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as well as taxpayers.
articles.abstract: Joseph A. Smith Jr., the nominee to lead the Federal Housing Finance Agency, faces the huge job of figuring how to protect Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as well as taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DECIDING what to do with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the taxpayer-owned mortgage giants that helped set the financial crisis in motion, will be a huge job for Congress next year.

articles.headline: Batting Cleanup at Bank of America
articles.snippet: Since taking over as C.E.O., Brian Moynihan has stabilized Bank of America, but he is still grappling with his predecessors’ acquisitions, like Countrywide.
articles.abstract: Since taking over as C.E.O., Brian Moynihan has stabilized Bank of America, but he is still grappling with his predecessors’ acquisitions, like Countrywide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charlotte, N.C.

articles.headline: No Jobs? Young Graduates Make Their Own
articles.snippet: You just graduated. Unemployment is 9.8 percent. And it costs next to nothing to start a business these days. Why not?
articles.abstract: You just graduated. Unemployment is 9.8 percent. And it costs next to nothing to start a business these days. Why not?
articles.lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, after graduating from New York University with a film degree and thousands of dollars in student loans, Scott Gerber moved back in with his parents on Staten Island. He then took out more loans to start a new-media and technology company, but he didn’t have a clear market in mind; the company went belly up in 2006.

articles.headline: Angry Birds, Flocking to Cellphones Everywhere
articles.snippet: A game is one of the least likely pop-culture crazes of the year, and perhaps the first to make the leap from cellphones to the mainstream.
articles.abstract: A game is one of the least likely pop-culture crazes of the year, and perhaps the first to make the leap from cellphones to the mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a tough sell: a game that involves catapulting birds at elaborate fortresses constructed by evil pigs.

articles.headline: Propping Up a Drug Lord, Then Arresting Him
articles.snippet: Hajji Juma Khan, described as an Afghan drug lord, was also a longtime informer for the Central Intelligence Agency and other agencies.
articles.abstract: Hajji Juma Khan, described as an Afghan drug lord, was also a longtime informer for the Central Intelligence Agency and other agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Hajji Juma Khan was arrested and transported to New York to face charges under a new American narco-terrorism law in 2008, federal prosecutors described him as perhaps the biggest and most dangerous drug lord in Afghanistan, a shadowy figure who had helped keep the Taliban in business with a steady stream of money and weapons.

articles.headline: China’s Army of Graduates Struggles for Jobs
articles.snippet: Villagers who will work in China’s factories are in demand, but many college graduates seeking professional jobs find their value plunging.
articles.abstract: Villagers who will work in China’s factories are in demand, but many college graduates seeking professional jobs find their value plunging.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Liu Yang, a coal miner’s daughter, arrived in the capital this past summer with a freshly printed diploma from Datong University, $140 in her wallet and an air of invincibility.

articles.headline: A Secretive Banking Elite Rules Trading in Derivatives
articles.snippet: In theory, clearinghouses exist to safeguard the integrity of the multitrillion-dollar derivatives market. In practice, they also defend big banks’ dominance.
articles.abstract: In theory, clearinghouses exist to safeguard the integrity of the multitrillion-dollar derivatives market. In practice, they also defend big banks’ dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the third Wednesday of every month, the nine members of an elite Wall Street society gather in Midtown Manhattan.

articles.headline: As the Ground Shifts, Biden Plays a Bigger Role
articles.snippet: Halfway through a term in which the president has relied mostly on counsel from an inner circle, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s influence is growing.
articles.abstract: Halfway through a term in which the president has relied mostly on counsel from an inner circle, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s influence is growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It was the end of a long and testy gripe session with House Democrats on Wednesday, and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had had enough.

articles.headline: Risky Borrowers Find Credit Again, at a Price
articles.snippet: Lenders are again offering credit to the riskier borrowers they once shunned, but they are choosing their prospects carefully and setting terms.
articles.abstract: Lenders are again offering credit to the riskier borrowers they once shunned, but they are choosing their prospects carefully and setting terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Credit card offers are surging again after a three-year slowdown, as banks seek to revive a business that brought them huge profits before the financial crisis wrecked the credit scores of so many Americans.

articles.headline: WikiLeaks Taps Power of the Press
articles.snippet: With each successive release of information, WikiLeaks has become more strategic and has been rewarded with deeper, more extensive coverage of its revelations.
articles.abstract: With each successive release of information, WikiLeaks has become more strategic and has been rewarded with deeper, more extensive coverage of its revelations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has WikiLeaks changed journalism forever?

articles.headline: More Christians Flee Iraq After New Violence
articles.snippet: A new wave of Iraqi Christians has fled to northern Iraq or abroad amid a campaign of violence against them.
articles.abstract: A new wave of Iraqi Christians has fled to northern Iraq or abroad amid a campaign of violence against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: QOSH, Iraq  A new wave of Iraqi Christians has fled to northern Iraq or abroad amid a campaign of violence against them and growing fear that the country’s security forces are unable or, more ominously, unwilling to protect them.

articles.headline: Web Focus Helps Revitalize The Atlantic
articles.snippet: To turn a profit for the first time in decade, one of the nation’s oldest magazines had to, more than anything else, stop thinking of itself as a printed product.
articles.abstract: To turn a profit for the first time in decade, one of the nation’s oldest magazines had to, more than anything else, stop thinking of itself as a printed product.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  How did a 153-year-old magazine  one that first published the “Battle Hymn of the Republic” and gave voice to the abolitionist and transcendentalist movements  reinvent itself for the 21st century?

articles.headline: As China Rolls Ahead, Fear Follows
articles.snippet: Some economists worry that inflation, government debt and asset bubbles could stall China next year.
articles.abstract: Some economists worry that inflation, government debt and asset bubbles could stall China next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI

articles.headline: Time Warner Views Netflix as a Fading Star
articles.snippet: Netflix, now the envy of the media world, had a lucrative contract with Starz that gave it cheap content. That deal is expiring, and rivals are gloating.
articles.abstract: Netflix, now the envy of the media world, had a lucrative contract with Starz that gave it cheap content. That deal is expiring, and rivals are gloating.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past year, executives at big media companies have watched Netflix with growing resentment  for its success in delivering movies and television shows via the Internet, for its stock price nearly quadrupling, for its chief executive being named businessperson of the year by Fortune magazine.

articles.headline: Madoff Lawsuits Are Headed for Court
articles.snippet: At least 1,000 individual civil suits can now go forward to try to recover more than $50 billion for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: At least 1,000 individual civil suits can now go forward to try to recover more than $50 billion for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the final deadline for litigation having passed at midnight on Saturday, at least 1,000 individual civil lawsuits will now go forward to try to recover more than $50 billion for the victims of the global Ponzi scheme orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Rep. Ron Paul, G.O.P. Loner, Comes In From Cold
articles.snippet: Ron Paul has often taken lonely stands in Congress. Now, others are beginning to credit him with wisdom.
articles.abstract: Ron Paul has often taken lonely stands in Congress. Now, others are beginning to credit him with wisdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As virtually all of Washington was declaring WikiLeaks’s disclosures of secret diplomatic cables an act of treason, Representative Ron Paul was applauding the organization for exposing the United States’ “delusional foreign policy.”

articles.headline: Facebook Wrestles With Free Speech and Civility
articles.snippet: With its prominence on the Web, the site’s role as an arbiter of free speech is likely to become more pronounced.
articles.abstract: With its prominence on the Web, the site’s role as an arbiter of free speech is likely to become more pronounced.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, likes to say that his Web site brings people together, helping to make the world a better place. But Facebook isn’t a utopia, and when it comes up short, Dave Willner tries to clean up.

articles.headline: In Tax Benefits to the Middle, Political Lift for Obama
articles.snippet: A hefty portion of the tax package will benefit middle-income Americans, and could pay political dividends to the president and Democrats.
articles.abstract: A hefty portion of the tax package will benefit middle-income Americans, and could pay political dividends to the president and Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the Senate poised to hold a key vote on Monday on the tax cut deal between President Obama and Republicans, the political jousting has focused on what the agreement does for the wealthy by extending all of the Bush-era tax rates, and for the unemployed, by continuing jobless aid.
